title: A poor American in Ireland and Scotland /
author: Goodkind, Ben.
snippet: It sti-uck me as being a homely one and yet it is not so bad, for there is antiquity back of it. Some of the other streets in Edinboro are named thus: Queen street, Inverleith Row, York Street, Chambers street. Castle Terrace, The Vennel, Greyfriars, Waterloo Place, Leith Walk, Bruntsfield street, George IV Bridge street, Teviot Place, Calton Hill, Lothian Road, Palmerston Place, Castle street, Princes street, etc.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: mother came, with that vigour which was only of half an hour's birth, and begotten by young conscience on old neglect. They had been trailing their legs along till they came to Inverleith Row, where he behoved to have left his companions, if his resolution lasted; for the road there goes straight on to Leith Harbour. He swithered, and made an effort; but S—k, who knew him, and fancied from the wild look of his eye that lie meditated throwing himself into the deep harbour of Leith, took him by an arm, motioning to W—pe to take the other, and thus by a very small effort—for really his resolution had departed, and his mind, so far as intention went, was gone—they half forced him up the long Row.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: They were now upon the low road leading parallel to the beach, and towards the end of Inverleith Row. Nor had the devil left them with the deserted toddy-bowl.

title: A second series of Curious storied traditions of Scottish life
author: Leighton, Alexander
snippet: Yet she trudged and trudged on, shutting her mouth against her empty stomach to keep out the cold north wind. She is at the foot of Inverleith Row, and her face is to the west; she will now escape the desultory blasts by keeping close by the long running dyke. She passes the scene

title: Bonnie Hills o'Hame, and other gems. [Verses.]
author: Scott, William
snippet: Of the numerous attractive scenes for the people about the Scottish capital, there are, I believe, none to equal the Royal Botanic Gardens wherein to spend a pleasant and profitable time. They are situated on the north side of the city, with two suitable entrances, one from Inverleith Row and the other by the west gate, leading from the direction of Stockbridge, where the car wends along to the terminus at Comely Bank. The situation is an admirably chosen one for various reasons, as such an extensive place would be very difficult to secure fulfilling the necessary requirements.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: Oh, that we re ceived the Spirit from on high, who might enable us to puri sy ourselves even as Christ is pure. If you have any parcel to send in, address it to Edinburgh, No. 7, Inverleith Row. We are very grateful to you for your generous offer of some Hawick bakes, which have long been famous.
